title: Fix links in docs
body:
Some of these links did not work when browsing documentation locally (with `cargo doc --open`) because, when viewing local files, browsers do not redirect `something/` links to `something/index.html` and just show all files in `something/` directory.

~I hope this doesn't break online docs browsing as I don't know how to check it.~
Edit: I have checked with local webserver and this works.

title: fix control-character parsing in windows
body:
Sorry for introducing a new bug in #619 

The bug is: when user enters `ctrl-g`, the result will be `G with modifier CONTROL`.  And we need to convert from upper case `G` to lowercase `g`.

This pr is trying to fix it.

Also fixes: #626 

Manual tested on both Windows and Ubuntu.

title: make windows key parsing logic better
body:
Handle #536 in windows

For more reference about the comment:
> The other implementation is to take the ASCII code produced by the key and bitwise AND it with 31, forcing bits 6 and 7 to zero. For example, pressing "control" and the letter "g" or "G" (code 107 in octal or 71 in base 10, which is 01000111 in binary), produces the code 7 (Bell, 7 in base 10, or 00000111 in binary).

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_character

And here:
> Pressing Ctrl together with a letter or other symbol written 10xxxxx₂ (binary notation) sends the control character whose code is 00xxxxx₂, e.g. Ctrl+[ sends character number 27₁₀ = 0011011₂ because [ is 91₁₀ = 1011011₂.

https://vi.stackexchange.com/questions/3225/disable-esc-but-keep-c

title: Documentation edit
body:
there was a mistake in docs. instead of using .execute command it was .queue command in Direct Execution.
and i added ? after the first .execute because you need to unwrap it before executing another command.

title: make KeyEvent::new a const fn
body:
This enables a more convenient declaration of const keys,
for example

```rs
pub const CONTROL_C: KeyEvent = KeyEvent::new(KeyCode::Char('c'), KeyModifiers::CONTROL);
```

Note that other functions could probably be made const, I changed only
this one because I very frequently declare const keys.

If you want I may have a wider look.

title: Remove deserialize_any and fix inconsitent serialize format.
body:
Fixes: #603 #601 

This PR removes `deserialize_any` which is according to the specs, not widely supported. One solution is to make everything an `str` such that serializing/deserializing is more simplistic.  Although it does feel hacky it might be a valid solution.

Also, the inconsistent format was due to the auto derive `Serialize` and custom implementation for `Deserialize`. Now they are both implemented manually.

title: Changed MoveToNextLine(0) and MoveToPreviousLine(0) to move 0 lines
body:
this pr specifies the minimum cursor line movement in commands `cursor::MoveToNextLine` and `cursor::MoveToPreviousLine` (see #599)

are there any exceptions to the behavior outlined in #599? i don't want to make a blanket statement that they will always move a minimum of 1 line, given 0.

title: Fix Greys in colors table
body:
I came across the same as issue #573. This PR makes the docs consistent with the code (I checked that `DarkGrey` is darker than `Grey` which is darker than `White`).

However, it should be noted that at least in the table [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ANSI_escape_code#3-bit_and_4-bit), "white" is what crossterm calls "grey", "bright black" or "gray" is what crossterm calls "dark grey" and "bright white" is what crossterm calls "white". With a quick search I couldn't find another good reference for these names.

title: Added Rusty Rain to list of used by
body: Added link to Rusty Rain's GitHub page.

title: Unify `Colorize` and `Styler` as `Stylize`
body:
`Colorize` and `Styler` were implemented on basically the exact same types, so I thought it would be easier if they used a single trait. I called it `Stylize` because the name `Styler` implies that the types implementing the trait are the ones doing the styling, when in fact it's the other way around. Naming traits after verbs is also fairly common (e.g. `Write`, `Clone`, `Borrow` etc).

A few other notes:
* I redesigned the trait itself to make it easier to implement and avoid the complex macro callback thing we had before. Instead of requiring implementations to implement all the methods themselves, they must simply provide access to a `ContentStyle`, and the trait can generate default implementations in terms of that.
* I moved `StyledContent::{with, on, attribute}` to the `Styled` trait to allow code like `"Hello!".on(Color::Black)`. Of course `"Hello!".on_black()` is better in that case but this method is nice to have. I'm not really sure about the naming here - `with`/`on` could also be called `foreground`/`background` like `ContentStyle` did, that might be more explicit.
* I implemented `Stylize` on `ContentStyle` to allow it to have all the convenience methods too. `ContentStyle::{foreground, background, attribute}` are no longer necessary as `Stylize::{with, on, attribute}` exist.
* I changed the implementation of `Display` on `StyledContent` to forward to `PrintStyledContent` to bring it in line with `Attribute` and to avoid printing useless ANSI escape sequences on older Windows.

title: Remove writer parameter from execute_winapi
body: The only command that used this parameter was `Print`, which we can force to call `write_command_ansi` with by always returning `true` from `is_ansi_code_supported`. This does mean that `Print` will no longer call `.flush()` on the writer when queued, but any bugs potentially caused by that can be mitigated by flushing before calling any WinAPI commands.

title: Update to signal-hook 0.3.8, signal-hook-mio 0.2.1
body:
Note, the documentation for creating an iterator from `&signals` suggests
it returns an infinite stream. I instead switched to `pending()`, since
presumably we don't want to block forever waiting for signals.

title: build(deps): update signal-hook to 0.1.17
body: Closes #544

title: Use io::Error for public error type
body:
This makes interoperation with the standard library much easier for users, which is especially useful given crossterm's low level APIs.

A custom error type is only useful if the context it provides outweighs its ergonomic burden, and in this case only the `ResizingTerminalFailure` and `SettingTerminalTitleFailure` variants were being used.

Do we have examples of these variants being used in dependent code? I can add them to the new representation if so.

title: refactor: fix clippy warnings
body:
All of the current PRs fail CI due to clippy failing on the main branch.
I fixed the errors that got returned. I had to change some internal
method signatures as some methods returned `Result<Option<T>>` but never
returned an error value, making the `Result` wrapping  unnecessary.

Updated two doc comments inside `event::KeyCode`.  

Using `KeyEvent::Char(...)` only gives me a compiler error; `KeyCode::Char(...)` is correct.

title: Add support for function keys F13...F20 on UNIX.
body: This adds support for function keys F13...F20 on UNIX.

title: KeyEvent case normalizing equality
body:
Manually implements `Eq`, `PartialEq` and `Hash` for `KeyEvent`

Adds:
* Manual implementation of `PartialEq` for `KeyEvent` with the property that lowercase ASCII characters are equal to uppercase in the presence of SHIFT modifiers and modifiers with SHIFT are equal to modifiers without SHIFT in the presence of an uppercase character. For example:
```rust
KeyEvent { code: Char( 'd',), modifiers: SHIFT } == KeyEvent { code: Char( 'D',), modifiers: SHIFT }
KeyEvent { code: Char( 'D',), modifiers: SHIFT } == KeyEvent { code: Char( 'D',), modifiers: NONE }
```
* Manual implementation of `Hash` for `KeyEvent` to preserve the property:
```
k1 == k2 -> hash(k1) == hash(k2)
```
* Private method `KeyEvent::normalize_case` that assists in implementation of `PartialEq` and `Hash`.
* Tests for the intended behavior of `Eq` and `Hash` on `KeyEvent`.

Closes #517.

Alacritty version - 0.7.1
tested with examples given, works as expected

title: Add examples to {Color, Colored}::parse_ansi
body: Doctests allow for the behaviour that is documented to be automatically tested. Obviously the actual tests below are more thorough, but I think it's still nice to have.

title: Remove extra Clone bounds in the style module
body: Since the print-like commands no longer require `Clone`, these functions don't need to either.

title: Fix clippy warnings
body: Rust 1.46 broke CI with the new `manual_range_contains` lint, so I fixed it up and CI should pass again.

title: Fixed typo in src/cursor.rs
body: Fixed a typo in cursor.rs which swapped up and down for `MoveToNextLine` and `MoveToPreviousLine` in the doc comments

title: Remove lazy_static dependency
body: This replaces the `lazy_static` dependency with either atomics or `parking_lot`'s const mutexes.

title: Inline ansi modules
body: Having separate modules that store the ANSI codes makes the codebase harder to read, as there is a layer of indirection. If they are inline, it reduces the number of lines of code, improves the usefullness of the `[src]` button in the documentation, and reduces the amount of jumping around required when reading or editing the code.

title: Support taking any Display in SetTitle
body: In terms of performance it should be the same - there are no extra allocations or anything.

title: Fix wrong resize size return.
body:
WINAPI: https://github.com/crossterm-rs/crossterm-winapi/pull/17

fixes: #507,

title: Make imports & docs more consistent
body: This PR makes the import ordering more consistent, and makes all the comments use `WinAPI` instead of `winapi`/`Winapi`/`WinApi`.

title: Replace AnsiType with write_ansi
Simplify ansi_support
body:
This greatly simplifies the `ansi_support` module.

- Instead of having a function to toggle vt processing it can only enable it, since that's all we do in Crossterm.
- Checking for a specific term is completely redundant since all that matters is that `$TERM` isn't `dumb`.
- It isn't necessary to attempt to enable ANSI support in terminal.rs since it's done automatically whenever a command is called.

title: Derive PartialEq and Eq for ContentStyle
Add support for combining some modifier keys
body: Partially helps with #515 but doesn't completely solve the issue, as it only really helps with the alt key and only on Unix systems. Getting ctrl+shift might be difficult though, as from my testing combining those keys outputs the same values to the buffer as just ctrl.

title: Disable the mouse capture in the demo to allow scrolling to work
body: The demo currently doesn't DisableMouseCapture if one runs the Event test. This stops my terminal from being able to scroll properly after the demo exits. This pull request simply DisableMouseCapture right before the test exits.

title: Add support for any event tracking
body: This adds support for any-event tracking, where all mouse movements are reported even if no buttons are held down. I used Xterm's [ctlseqs](https://invisible-island.net/xterm/ctlseqs/ctlseqs.html#h2-Mouse-Tracking) as reference, and I have tested this on URXVT, xterm, st and alacritty in both normal mode and SGR mode, and it seems to work fine.
